title.narrative: Sustainable Land Management in Highlands of Kilimanjaro

description.narrative: Reducing Land Degradation on the Highlands of Kilimanjaro Region

title.narrative: Sustainable Land Management in Highlands of Kilimanjaro

description.narrative: Reducing Land Degradation on the Highlands of Kilimanjaro Region
first-order administrative division
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Objective: "To provide land users and managers with the enabling environment (policy, financial, institutional, capacity) for SLM adoption in the Kilimanjaro region and country-wide
Extent of land under direct SLM in the project area and extent benefiting from upscaling

comment.narrative: Minimal land (14,398.00 ha) being managed in accordance with principles of SLM or integrated water and land management as follows: Moshi DC 2,500.00, Moshi MC 670, Same 200, Mwanga 53, Rombo 750, Hai 9975, and Siha 250

Over 65,141 ha under direct SLM (project pilot area) and another 40,821 ha impacted by up-scaling in during the project\'s 4 yrs; an additional 1,000,000 benefit through upscaling of lessons through the National Dialogue and the SLM Investment Framework

This indicator has exceeded (100%) its target in terms of land directly under SLM (74,532.59 out of the targeted 68,141.4 ha) in the project catchment areas is directly under SLM. Contribution by each administrative council is as follows: Moshi DC: 16,439.24 out of 13,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (2,200.00 ha), rehabilitation of gullies (1,000.00), actual terraces (7,551.00), land below terraces (150.00), land protected by cut-off drains (1,295.70), river bank protection (25.00), protection of water sources (35.20), apiaries (1,974.29), irrigation (89.05), sub-soiling (15.00), reforestation (2,104.00); Moshi MC 656.55 out of 1,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (47.30 ha), woodlots (15.00), rehabilitation of gullies (260.00), river bank protection (25.00), water sources (55.00), apiaries (250.00), irrigation (0.25), reforestation (4.00); Same 858.80 out of 700.00 ha under agro-forestry (150.00 ha), rehabilitation of gullies (100.00), actual terraces (97.80), below terraces (100.00), water harvesting (75.00), apiaries (155.00), irrigation (81.00), conservation agriculture (90.00), reforestation (10.00); Mwanga 37,734.00 out of 29,736.00 ha under woodlots (2,445.00 ha), actual terraces (19,516.00), below terraces (15,325.00), river bank protection (15.00), water sources (40.00), apiaries (30.00), irrigation (360.00), conservation agriculture (3.00) Rombo 3,263.00 out of 3,305.00 ha under agro-forestry (500.00 ha), woodlots (25.00), rehabilitation of gullies (30.00), actual terraces (1,000.00), below terraces (500.00), river bank protection (15.00), water sources (15.00) apiaries (25.00), poultry (3.00), and reforestation (150.00); Hai 13,598.00 out of 16,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (9,062.95 ha), woodlots (15.00), river bank protection (2,561.00), apiaries (1,063.00), irrigation (0.05), reforestation (896.00); and Siha 1,983.00 out of 1,400.00 ha under agro-forestry (800.00 ha), woodlots (1.00), actual terraces (643.00), below terraces (500.00) river bank protection (10.00) apiaries (3.00), irrigation (1.00), and conservation agriculture (25.00). Four districts, Siha, Same, Mwanga, and Moshi DC have exceeded their targets for land directly under SLM within the catchment areas. With respect to by upscaling, 26,978.00 ha of land have been impacted out of 40,821 (about 66%). The breakdown of data is as follows: Same District - 2000 ha; Mwanga District-157; Moshi Municipal Council-3500.00; Moshi District-2000; Rombo District-192; Siha 1129.0 ha, and Hai District-18000.00 ha. The reason for this low percentage in land impacted by upscaling is that the project experienced significant delays in its implementation. The drivers behind the late start of implementation are related to recruitment and administrative procedures, as well as the time needed to engage stakeholders and set-up the management structures. Activity implementation only commenced in 2012 instead of 2010. With such a delay, the project focussed more on achieving the primary target, i.e., land directly under SLM than on upscaling.
The reason for this low percentage in land impacted by upscaling is that the project experienced significant delays in its implementation. The drivers behind the late start of implementation are related to recruitment and administrative procedures, as well as the time needed to engage stakeholders and set-up the management structures. Activity implementation only commenced in 2012 instead of 2010. With such a delay, the project focussed more on achieving the primary target, i.e., land directly under SLM than on upscaling.

description.narrative: Reduction in soil erosion

comment.narrative:
More than 70% (924,600.30 ha) of land experiencing serious forms of erosion, with several erosion gulleys in zone 3
In 2005-06, minimum suspended sediment was 13.0-1132.3 tonnes/day.
No gully rehabilitated within the project catchments

The highest mean concentration of sediments as measured at the TPC (Tanzania Plantation Company) estate gauging station on Kikuletwa River within the Pangani River Basin in 2014 was 33.67 mg/l, compared to 1136.5 in 2006, resulting in a reduction of -1102.83 mg/l (>100%). Within the same period in the same basin, measurements at Ruvu River at Kifaru gauging station reveal that highest mean concentration (mg/l) was 24.33, compared to 42.8 in 2006, a reduction of -18.46 (43%). There over 100 gullies within the project area. Rehabilitating all of them was beyond the financial resources of the project considering that gully rehabilitation was only one of the hundred activities. As such, based on priorities by Ward Development Committees in the districts using gully size, and threat posed to properties, especially houses and cultivated land, each district (except Siha where there are no gullies) targeted to rehabilitate 2 gullies. To date, 6 gullies out of 12 have been rehabilitated, i.e., 50%. Two more are under rehabilitation, the rest will be rehabilitated before the end of the project. To date, through agro-forestry, woodlots, river bank protection, reforestation, etc., there is an improvement in ground cover by at least 60% (39,252.25 ha of the 65,141.00).

description.narrative: Reduction in the rates of deforestation

comment.narrative: Currently estimated area of degraded land is 1.8% (23,026.04 ha in 2014) ; there are several seriously degraded patches of woodlands
At least 25% recovery in highly degraded patches as measured by regeneration (recruitment) and improvements in species index for forests/woodlands and reduction in area of degraded land

No measurements of regeneration (recruitment) and improvements in species index for forests/woodlands and reduction in area of degraded land. However, as stated before, through agro-forestry, woodlots, and reforestation (18,425.25 ha), and with a recovery rate of survival is 80%, there is at least 67% reduction of the degraded land, i.e.,18,3425.25 out of 23,026.04 ha.

description.narrative: Carbon mitigated from energy switch and improved energy efficiencies

comment.narrative: Currently over 90% of energy needs in the region being met from wood, with minimal effort at improved efficiencies or energy switch.
At least half a million tons of carbon dioxide mitigated by mid-term from institutional adoption of energy switch and improved energy efficiencies; and, a million cumulative at the end of the project

The project facilitated the design of a Project Identification Note (PIN) for a carbon-credit-earning scheme for public institutions, based on subsitituting biomass energy with methane generated form human waste, likely to be implemented through the UNDP Millennium Development Goal Carbon Initiative, and other carbon market schemes. The PIN was submitted to the Designated national Authority (NOA) for a Letter of No Objection to design a Project Document, which is the Division of Environment in the Vice President's Office in 2014, but the project still awaits the approval of the PIN by this department. This stalemate notwithstanding, the project identified 901 households that is providing with subsidized wood-saving or fuel-efficient stoves. The criteria used to select the beneficiaries included factors such as use of sustainable land-management techniques, e.g., soil and water conservation measures, agro-forestry, woodlots, bee-keeping, etc., and ability to contribute 20% of cost (TZS 300,000.00) of construction of the stove. In Moshi Municipality the stoves have been installed in 31 households. Firewood consumption per household before installation of fuel-efficient stoves was 7.3 tonnes annum, resulting in 13.3 tonnes of carbon dioxide being emitted. Introduction of wood-saving stoves led to substantive reduction in the use of firewood (3.6 tonnes per household per annum and emission of CO2 (6.5 tonnes per household per annum).

description.narrative: Change in household wellbeing

comment.narrative: More than 75% of households below the UN defined poverty line

At least 25% improvement in household welfare for a minimum of 50% of the households in pilot districts, as measured by percentage increase in household income, percentage reduction in number of food insecure days etc.

There is >100% increase on average in household income for households participating in SLM activities. In Rombo, it increased from TZS 600,000.00 per annum before to TZS 900,000 (50%) after; in Moshi DC it increased from TZS 365,000.00 pa before to TZS 1,460,000.00 (300%) after, and in Siha the increase is from TZS 480,000.00 to TZS 1,080,000.00 (125%). In Moshi MC, it increased from TZS 766,500.00 to 821,00.00 (7%). In Hai from TZS 912,000.00 to 1,168,000.00 (28%). In Mwanga, the increase is 200% from 500000 to TZS 1,500,000.00, and in Same by 100% from TZS 180,000.00 to 360,000.00. In terms of food insecure days, there is an average reduction of 43% from 95 to 53 days. In Rombo, the decline is 185 to 90 days, in Moshi DC 90 to 45, and in Siha 90 to 60. In Moshi MC, the reduction is from 60 to 40 days (33%). In Hai from 35 to 31 days (11%). In Mwanga from 120 to 90 days (25%), and in Same by 33% from 120 to 80 days. These changes have occurred because many farmers have now adopted SLM measures including conservation agriculture, on-farm rain water harvesting by sub-soiling, tree planting, production of improved coffee, production of improved fruits, soil erosion control by contour terracing. As reported earlier on, land under direct SLM in the districts is as follows: 15, 834.95 ha out of the target of 13,000.00 ha in Moshi District, 3,263.00 out of 3,305.00 ha in Rombo, 1,983.00 out of 1,480.00 in Siha. Household welfare has also increased significantly from increased productivity of crops for farmers taking up SLM practices advocated by the project. The regional average crop yield has improved for main crops such as banana from 24.3 to 38tonnes/ha, maize from 4.2 to 9.5 t/ha, and coffee from 0.5 to 1.1 t/ha amongst households that are participating in the project. Specifically, data from districts indicate that in Rombo, banana yield increased from 11.3 to 12.0 t/ha, and 0.6 to 1.0 t/ha of maize. In Moshi DC, banana yield improved from 10.0 to 14 t/ha, maize from 2.0 to 4.0 t/ha, and coffee from 0.1 to 0.8 t/ha. In Siha, banana yield changed from 3.0 to 12.0 t/ha, maize from 1.6 to 4.5 t/ha and coffee from 0.2 to 0.3 t/ha. With such increases in crop yields, its not surprising that the household well-being has changed for the better as a result of the project. On the other hand, crop yields amongst non-participating households have remained static, e.g., 24.3 tonnes of bananas per ha, 3.6 tonnes of maize/ha and 0.6 tonnes of coffee per ha.

description.narrative: Number of policies mainstreaming SLM

comment.narrative: All policy statements mention importance of SLM but don't have details of how SLM will be ensured
At least 3 policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM;

Policy Review is a lengthy process in the sense that once a need to review a policy has been identified, a brief is prepared for the relevant Ministry which approves it. Once approved, the review is commissioned. When the review process is concluded, the cabinet, and then parliament has to ratify the new policy or legislation. Given this lengthy process, it is unlikely that any policy or legislation can be ratified or amended respectively within the lifetime of this project. However, a study on Policy Review, harmonization, and traditional institutions in natural resources management was commissioned by the project. It had 3 phases, i.e., Phase I - Assessment, documentation and Publication on Indigenous Institutions and Knowledge in Natural Resource Management in Project Pilot Districts, Phase II- Assessment to which national policies are implemented on the ground, identifying pull and push factors influencing either implementation or lack thereof, and Phase III- Assessment of the extent to which productive sector policies mainstream Sustainable Land Management principles. This study resulted in 3 policy briefs, 1 for each phase. Specifically the study on Phase III reveals that 12 twelve sectoral policies that impinge upon natural resources management in the region were analysed to determine the extent to which they have mainstreamed SLM principles such as i) Improved land productivity; ii) Improved livelihoods; and iii) Improved ecosystems. The study revealed that only six (50%) sector policies have adequately mainstreamed the SLM principles. Five (42%) and one (8%) of the sector policies have moderately mainstreamed and slightly mainstreamed the principles. The study also revealed that the key challenge in mainstreaming of SLM principles is shortage of human and financial resources. As such, the study, and subsequently the policy brief for Phase III recommended that for effective mainstreaming of the SLM principles sufficient budgetary allocations are needed for effective implementation of SLM principles. For this to be achieved, there is need for political support to mainstream the SLM Principles into the pertinent policies. It would thus recommended be appropriate that there is concerted efforts by both NRM experts and politicians to ensure that the process of mainstreaming is successful. The brief has since been submitted to the Office of Vice President so that the recommendation is included in the Policy Review process of the Environmental Policy and Environmental which is underway. The Project is keenly following up on the policy briefs that have been submitted.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Policy and institutional support
Number of policies with legislation and institutional arrangement for effective implementation

comment.narrative: Policy implementation very weak due to weak judiciary and inadequate understanding of, and buy-in for the policies form local communities

At least 3 key policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM; Legislation and institutional arrangement guiding policy implementation for at least 3 key policies are influenced by project results and overtly recognize SLM principles; Local level governance of SLM improved by incorporation of traditional regulations into bye laws with clear implementation mechanisms The National SLM Investment Strategy formulated and delivering additional finances for upscaling SLM

A study on Policy Review, harmonization, and traditional institutions in natural resources management was commissioned by the project. It had 3 phases, i.e., Phase I - Assessment, documentation and Publication on Indigenous Institutions and Knowledge in Natural Resource Management in Project Pilot Districts, Phase II- Assessment to which national policies are implemented on the ground, identifying pull and push factors influencing either implementation or lack thereof, and Phase III- Assessment of the extent to which productive sector policies mainstream Sustainable Land Management principles. This study resulted in 3 policy briefs, 1 for each phase. Specifically the study on Phase I recommends integration of traditional institutions and knowledge into the formal institutions and structures for effective implementation of SLM practices. As is the case with Phase III, the study came up with a policy brief that has numerous recommendations, two of which are as follows: i) it would be appropriate if policy makers could be actively involved in the promotion and integration of indigenous products such farm yard manure and compost into modernity. This recommendation will address the issue of modernity and reliance on market economy, which accounts for the low rate of use of indigenous practices while encouraging democratic governance that allows the majority decision to rule even in matters that have indigenously been managed through cultural norms and beliefs; and ii) there is a need for policy recognition of indigenous methods as part of superior ways in solving some of the problems facing land and natural resource management in general. Therefore, there is a need to establish a communication forum with the remaining traditional leaders that could empower them in sustainable land management. Just like the policy brief for Phase III, the brief for Phase I has been submitted to the Office of the Vice President.

description.narrative: Markets support expansion of livelihood options in Kilimanjaro to reduce pressure on agriculture and natural resources and increase income
Percentage of cooking energy for institutions being met from alternatives

comment.narrative: Currently 100% of energy for cooking being met from wood
At least 40% of energy for cooking in the public institutions being met from alternatives and the rest being derived in highly efficient systems

As reported previously, the project commissioned a study on Fuel-efficient Technologies, which was undertaken by Mutimba. The findings of the Mutimba report can be accessed on http://www.kilimanjaro.go.tz/kurasa/habari_moto/hm3/index2.php. Phase II, of the study used the information to design a carbon finance project for public institutions based on the energy switch principle, in line with UNDPs MDG Carbon Finance pilots. Under this phase, the project facilitated the design of a Project Identification Note (PIN) for a carbon-credit-earning scheme for public institutions, based on subsitituting biomass energy with methane generated from human waste, likely to be implemented through the UNDP Millennium Development Goal Carbon Initiative, and other carbon market schemes. Phase II found that some institutions are better prepared than others to move to the next phase of the project, based on following criteria:
i) The type of cook stoves in use should be energy-saving
ii) Operation and maintenance of the stoves properly operated and serviced
iii) Physical condition of the stoves should be good
iv) Energy initiatives in place wood lot, solar, biogas.
While they may not have excelled in all the areas listed above, the following institutions did well in at least three of them.
i) Visitation secondary school
ii) Orkolili secondary school
iii) Tarakea secondary school
iv) Karanga Prison
v) The Police
vi) Kibosho hospital
The above institutions were recommended to benefit from the Carbon Finance Project. Again, as reported before, the project formulated a Project Idea Note (PIN), which was submitted to the Designated national Authority (NOA) for a Letter of No Objection to design a Project Document, which is the Division of Environment in the Vice President's Office in 2014, but the project still awaits the approval of the PIN by this department. Consequent upon this stalemate, there is no cooking energy for institutions being met from alternatives

description.narrative: Amounts of money being earned by the public institutions from sale of carbon credits

comment.narrative: Currently none
public institutions sell at least 500,000 to 1 million tonnes of carbon by end of the project

No carbon credits sold yet. Institutions need to be assisted to develop the carbon finance project, market it and implement the improved energy measures (replacing wood with methane generated from human and kitchen waste, replacing inefficient kilns and burners with more efficient ones, etc.), before carbon credits can be earned and sold. Greenhouse gases targeted are Methane (CH4) and Carbon dioxide (CO2). Type of activities of the envisaged project include installation of biogas digester and supporting infrastructure, installation of biogas cookers in place of biomass stoves, and training of kitchen staff in the operation and maintenance of the new cooking system. The designed PIN estimates that Up to a period of 10 years 52,387tCO2-equivalent would be sequestered. However, as reported above, the carbon project is still at the PIN stage. Without the approval of the PIN by the National Approving Authority, the project cannot be designed.

description.narrative: Number of farmers participating in shade coffee marketing and amounts of money earned

comment.narrative:
Shade coffee project reaching a small group of coffee farmers (less than 15%); Rombo 1312 farmers with (TZS 178.75 billion pa)
Siha District-2025 coffee farmers marketing their coffee as shade coffee out of 20,545 (9.8%) with TZS 30.79 billion pa, Moshi DC 15, 367 farmers earning TZS 1,746,00 000,000, Hai 10,519 farmers making TZS 7,700,000,000.00 pa, and Mwanga 439 farmers, making TZS 50,748,500.00
At least 20% increase in the number of coffee farmers marketing their coffee as shade coffee

Regionally, there has been an increase of about 6% in the number of farmers that market their coffee as shade coffee, i.e., from 29,662 to 31,423 based on data from the 5 districts which grow coffee. By district, the numbers changed from 15,367 to 16,392 in Moshi DC, Siha (from 2,025 to 2,124), Mwanga 439 to 639, Rombo 1,312 to 1,749 while the number remained static in Hai at 10,519. This increase has led to a concomitant increase in the amount of money earned. Regionally, the increase is approximately 51.6% from 40,471,498, 500.00 to TZS 61,369, 832, 000.00. At district level, the increase is from TZS 7.7 to 8.5 billion in Hai, Moshi DC TZS 1.7 to 5.9 billion, Rombo TZS 178.7 to 440.0 billion, TZS 30.7 to 46.4 billion in Siha, and TZS 50.7 to 70.8 million in Mwanga. These achievements have been made especially because the project provided training to farmers in production of high quality coffee. The actual number of farmers is unlikely to reach the target because the drop in coffee prices has discouraged them from maintaining coffee production. However, it is hoped that with the increase in income generated by those farmers trained by the project more farmers will revert back to coffee cultivation and sell it as shade coffee. The other factor is that the project delayed to start implementing, which also affected this activity. The coffee trees that have just been planted after interventions by the project will take years 3 to 4 years, which is beyond this project's lifetime. The project, however, is againg confident that once the new plants start yielding coffee, farmers will be motivated to emualte the early adapters, hence the number of those producing and marketing their coffee as a specialty will increase.

description.narrative: Access to micro-finance and credits

comment.narrative: Less than 10% of farmers have access to micro-finance and credits. Siha 7849, Moshi MC 59 farmers, Hai 3376, Moshi DC 1,920, Rombo 696, Same 150.
At least 25% increase in number of farmers accessing micro-finance and credit

There is an increase in the number of farmers accessing finance and credit >100%, i.e., from 14,050 to 24,291. A breakdown by district is given below as follows: Siha District- from 7,849 to 8,614 farmers, an increase of 9.7% Rombo District- 696 to 1,182 farmers (69.8%) Hai District- 3,376 to 12,575 (272%), Moshi DC 0% increase, Moshi MC from 59 to 259 (339%), Mwanga from 0 to 14,260, and Sae from 150 to 400 (167%). The project helped the farmers to establish viable enterprises, and supported them in formalization of different producer groups to the extent that they attained legal status. These are some of the conditions that must be fulfilled for user groups to access finance and credit services from financial institutions.

description.narrative: Number of new viable business as an avenue for energizing local economic development

comment.narrative: Limited opportunities for markets due to very few agro processing businesses, hence agricultural produce difficult to market
At least 3 agri-processing business established and making contribution to local economic development and SLM

Three enterprises have been established so far, i.e., bee-keeping, poultry, and mushroom production. These enterprises are at various stages of development; some are already generating income while others have just been established. Bee-keeping has been established in all the 7 councils, i.e., Siha, Hai, Moshi District, Moshi Municipality, Mwanga, Rombo, and Same. A total of 44 groups have been formed, i.e., 4 in Siha, Hai (11), Moshi MC (5), Same (4), Mwanga 5, Moshi DC (9), and Rombo (6), with membership varying from 77 in Siha to 252 in Hai, the total being 866. Seven hundred and seventy-four (774) hives have been distributed. To date a total 951 liters of honey has been harvested (350.0 ltrs in Hai), Moshi DC (0), Same 346, Siha 65.8, Mwanga (0) and Rombo 99.5. In terms of income, a total of TZS 9.1 million has been realized as follows: Siha (TZS 0.47); Hai (3.5); Moshi MC (0.9), Moshi DC (0), Rombo (0.99), Mwanga (0), and Same (3.2). To add value to the honey that will be harvested, the Project has bought a honey-processing machine which is being installed at a centre. With regard to poultry, the Project has established a total of 15 poultry groups. In Moshi DC (6), 5 in Rombo, and 4 in Mwanga. Chicken houses have been built, the project will provide chickens (layers), feed, medication, and drinking troughs. Moshi DC and Rombo have made considerable progress in poultry with 303 and 200 birds respectively. So far, Moshi, Rombo and Mwanga districts they have produced 14,700, 2,009, and 790 eggs respectively and sold 13,340, 1,900 and 790 which they have generated TZS 4.0 , 0.47, and TZS 0.22 million respectively. The remaining eggs are being hatched so the pullets can be shared amongst the group members. Regarding mushroom production, the project has worked to establish and develop a mushroom collection and processing centre by engaging into the following: Strengthening Hai Mushroom Growers Association (HAMUG) by facilitating them to undertake registration process which involved technical support to develop a constitution and file application for registration. The organization was registered at district level. 4 meetings were also held to assist the organization develop operating procedure that will ensure them reach better markets and coordinate production and marketing amongst its members; Building capacity of mushroom growers on value addition; provision of equipment including 4 mushroom solar driers and 1 autoclave machine; and Provision of material and technical support for increasing production capacity, e.g., 200 bottles for seed production and Agar solution. The total production of mushroom is 112kg/week, which means 5,824 kg/yr. 243 kg/week of addtional fresh mushroom is dried into is 27.00 kg/week, which 1,404kg/year. Revenue realized is TZS 5,000.00/kg of fresh mushroom generating TZS 29120000.00 per year,while dry mushroom is sold at TZS 60,000.00/kg, realizing TZS 84,240,000.00 per year.

description.narrative: Institutions with capacities to increase knowledge, skills, technologies and change in attitude for adoption and adaptation of SLM
Number of people with relevant skills for SLM

comment.narrative: Less than 20% of land users have modern skills for improved management; less than 50% of technical officers have updated SLM skills

At least 40% of land users and 30% of technical officers requiring to update skills have done so by mid-term: by the end of project, at least 60% of land users and 75% of technical officers cumulatively have updated skills.

At least 59,237 farmers out of 118,500 (50%) and 265 officers out of 491 (54 %) updated their skills. Results by district are as shown below. Siha District-10,465 (44.4%) out of 23,545 land users have acquired necessary skills on SLM , while 53 (>100%) technical officers out of 13 had updated skills on SLM, Rombo District-713 farmers out of 3858 (18.5%) and 41 technical officers out of 40 (>100%) got skills of SLM (beekeeping, nursery establishment, soil and water conservation structures). Hai District- 63 out of 243 technical officers equivalent to 54 % of officers requiring to update skills have done so, while land users it is 78.8%, i.e., 20,320 out of 25,783 (previus count included outside of catchment, i.e whole district). Moshi District-2,187 land users out of 27,612 (7.9%) and 59 technical staff out 64 (92.1%) in the catchment requiring to update skill have done so. In Moshi MC, 372 farmers out of 602 (61.8%) and 30 out 36 (83.3%) have attained relevant SLM skills. In Mwanga 24,780 out of 35,400 farmers and 25 out of 25 (100%) officers have attained SLM skills. In Same, 400 out of 1700 farmers (23.5%) and 19 out of 30 (63%) officers have attained SLM skills.

description.narrative: Percentage of land and resource users adopting improved practices

comment.narrative: Less than 10% engaging in 1-2 improved practices consistently
At least 40% of farmers adopting 3-5 forms of improved practices by mid-term and 50% cumulatively by project end

This target has been achieved, i.e., 50% of land users, i.e., 59,208 out of 118,500 land and resource users have adopted improved practices, such as wood-saving stoves, terracing as a soil and water conservation measure, tree-planting, bee keeping, etc. Siha District- 12,590 (54%) of land users out of 23,545 adopting 3-5 forms of improved practices (terracing, tree planting, river bank protection) Rombo District- 480 out of 3858 (12.4%) engage in improved practices (modern beekeeping, soil and water conservation measures, crop selection and tree planting) in the catchment. Moshi District- 1,053 out of 27,612 (3.8%) participated in rain-water harvesting on farms using a sub-soiling technology, improved poultry management, improved bee-keeping, and tree planting. Hai District- 19,596 out of 25,783 (48600 used previous year was for whole district) equivalent to 76.0 % of land users have adopted 1 forms of improved land-use practices, i.e., tree planting, terracing, and beekeeping. In Moshi MC, 449 out of 602 land users (74.6%), Mwanga 24,780 out of 35,400 (70%), and Same, 260 out of 1,700 (15.3%) land users adopting improved practices.

description.narrative: Knowledge and skills for SLM provided to resource managers at all levels
Change in agricultural productivity

comment.narrative: Current low and declining, exact levels of selected crops to be obtained during inception
At least 20% increase in agricultural produce for key crops for those adopting 3-5 improved practices consistently by mid-term and 50% cumulative by project end

description.narrative: Number of farmers using up-to-date weather information in decision making

comment.narrative: Tanzania has relatively good weather data less than 10% of farmers in the Kilimanjaro region use weather data for decision making
At least 35% of farmers using up-to-date information from weather stations to determine planting/harvesting dates by mid-term and at least 50% by end of project;

Data collection has just commenced now that the project managed to procure automated weather equipment that has just been installed by the Tanzania Meteorological Agency. To date, Hai has 12,665 households that use weather data for decision making. This section will be updated once all the data has been collected.

description.narrative: Adoption of improved kilns in carbonization

comment.narrative: Less than 10% use improved kilns in carbonization
Number of charcoal producers using improved kiln in carbonization in pilot districts increase by at least 30% by mid-term and a cumulative 50% by project end

The regional government in Kilimanjaro outlawed charcoal, implying that it did not want to hear anything about charcoal being made whether efficiently or in a sustainable manner. For the same reason not many people openly to talk about charcoal. However, in June 2015, the project sponsored senior officials of the regional government to attend a workshop on Tree-based bioenergy in Sub-Saharan Africa in Nairobi which discussed opportunities and challenges. Lessons from the workshop may influence how the regional officials now view charcoal. This is especially important because the project has commissioned a study to review policies and regulations on charcoal. However, no matter how positively charcoal may now be perceived, the project has lost an opportunity to improve carbonization by charcoal producers. So, it can only be hoped that such activities will happen at a later stage.
